revision.comment: /* Campaigning work */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: McCann’s → McCann's (2)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox MLA |honorific-prefix = |name = Eamonn McCann |honorific-suffix = |image = File:Eamonn McCann.jpg |imagesize = |alt = |caption = Eamonn McCann (centre), on a march against austerity in Belfast, October 2012 |office = |term_start = |term_end = |predecessor = |successor = |office2 = [[Member of the Legislative Assembly (Northern Ireland)|Member of the Legislative Assembly]]
for [[Foyle (Assembly constituency)|Foyle]] |assembly2 = Northern Ireland |majority2 = |term_start2 = 5 May 2016 |term_end2 = 26 January 2017 |predecessor2 = [[Gerard Diver]] |successor2 = ''[[Assembly Members (Reduction of Numbers) Act (Northern Ireland) 2016|Seat abolished]]'' |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1943|03|10|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Derry]], [[Northern Ireland]] |death_date = |death_place = |birthname = |nationality = |party = [[People Before Profit Alliance]] |relations = |children = 3 |residence = |alma_mater = [[Queen's University Belfast]] }} '''Eamonn McCann''' (born 10 March 1943{{cite web|title=Mr Eamonn McCann|url=http://aims.niassembly.gov.uk/mlas/details.aspx?&aff=11873&per=5807&sel=5&ind=&prv=0|website=Northern Ireland Assembly|publisher=Northern Ireland Assembly|accessdate=17 May 2016}}) is an Irish politician, journalist and [[Activism|political activist]] from [[Derry]], [[Northern Ireland]]. In the [[Northern Ireland Assembly election, 2016|2016 Northern Ireland Assembly election]], he was elected as an [[Member of the Legislative Assembly|MLA]] for the [[Foyle (Assembly constituency)|Foyle]] constituency. He served for nearly 9 months before losing his seat in [[Northern Ireland Assembly election, 2017|2017]]. ==Early life and education== McCann was born and has lived most of his life in Derry. Raised Catholic, he attended [[St. Columb's College]] and is prominently featured in the documentary film, ''The Boys of St. Columb's''. He later attended [[Queen's University Belfast]], where he was president of the [[Literary and Scientific Society (Queen's University Belfast)|Literary and Scientific Society]], the university's debating society.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} ==Career== As a young man he was one of the original organisers of the [[Derry Housing Action Committee]] (DHAC), a radical campaign group focusing on access to social housing. DHAC organised, in conjunction with the [[Northern Ireland Civil Rights Association]] (NICRA), the second civil rights march in Northern Ireland. This march, which took place on 5 October 1968, is generally seen as the birth date of the [[Northern Ireland Civil Rights Movement]]. His political contemporaries included [[Bernadette Devlin]], for whom he served as an election agent.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} He stood for election in the [[Foyle (Northern Ireland Parliament constituency)|Foyle constituency]] at the [[Northern Ireland general election, 1969|1969 Northern Ireland general election]] for the [[Northern Ireland Labour Party]], placing third with 1,993 votes (12.3% of the total).{{cite web|url=http://www.election.demon.co.uk/stormont/ldrcity.html|title=Northern Ireland Parliamentary Election Results: Boroughs: Londonderry}} He was tried (as one of the so-called [[Raytheon 9]]) in Belfast in May–June 2008 over alleged damage caused during the [[2006 Lebanon War|2006 War on Lebanon]] to a facility operated by multinational arms company [[Raytheon]] in Derry. The jury unanimously acquitted McCann, and all the other defendants, of charges of criminal damage to property belonging to Raytheon. The jury had heard that the groups's actions were prompted by repeated bombing of Lebanese property in which numerous civilians died and the wish to protect those lives and that property from being attacked by Israeli forces with weapons, weaponry systems and missiles supplied by Raytheon. The judge dismissed charges of [[affray]] after hearing the prosecution evidence. However, McCann was convicted of the theft of two computer discs, for which he received a 12-month conditional discharge.{{cite news|url=http://www.derryjournal.com/journal/Raytheon6-cleared.4176443.jp|title=Raytheon 6 cleared|work=[[Derry Journal]]|date=11 June 2008|accessdate=2 January 2016}} In a statement outside the court McCann said: "[We] have been vindicated. ... The jury have accepted that we were reasonable in our belief that ... Israeli ... Forces were guilty of war crimes in Lebanon in the summer of 2006. The action we took was intended to have, and did have, the effect of hampering or delaying the commission of war crimes". His appearance at the funeral of former PIRA volunteer, Old Bailey bomber, and republican activist [[Dolours Price]], and a tribute he paid to her, was criticised by a son-in-law of [[Jean McConville]], who was kidnapped, tortured and murdered by the [[PIRA]]. Price was suspected of being one of the paramilitaries who took part.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0219/1224264799917.html|title=Price offers to help locate 'disappeared'|work=[[The Irish Times]]|date=19 February 2010|accessdate=20 February 2010}}{{cite news|title=Arrest Adams Now|work=[[Sunday Life (newspaper)|Sunday Life]]|date=21 February 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wbur.org/2013/04/15/ira-tapes-boston-college|title=Boston College IRA interviews update|work=[[WBUR-FM]]|accessdate=21 December 2015}} McCann explained that her family had asked him to speak at her funeral. He said: "I don't think I said anything at Dolours Price's grave that contradicted that [calling McConville's murder 'a horrible and unforgivable act'] ... The point I had in mind, the point I was making, was there are some people deeply implicated in the cruel murder of Mrs McConville who appear not to be undergoing any inner turmoil. They appear to find it very easy to handle the knowledge of their own involvement in that murder".{{cite web|url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/headlines/mcconville-relative-raps-socialist-for-dolours-price-tribute-1-4733840|title=McConville relative raps socialist for Dolours Price tribute|work=[[The News Letter]]|date=30 January 2013|accessdate=2 January 2016}} He was elected as an [[Member of the Legislative Assembly|MLA]] for [[Foyle (Assembly constituency)|Foyle]] in May 2016 but lost his seat in January 2017. While the number of seats in the Foyle constituency was reduced from six to five, McCann and People before Profit attracted criticism from [[Sinn Féin]] and pro-European activists for supporting [[Brexit]] in an area with the 4th highest remain vote (out of approximately 400 counting areas) in the whole of the United Kingdom. {{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/politics/northern-ireland-constituencies/N06000008|title=Foyle – Northern Ireland Assembly constituency – Election 2016|work=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=7 May 2016}} http://www.sinnfein.ie/contents/42032 Nonetheless, McCann's vote increased in the 2017 election and he came close to taking the fifth seat from the DUP. ==Campaigning work== McCann was central to the setting up of the Bloody Sunday Justice Campaign; the role of his investigative journalism and decades of campaigning for justice for the Bloody Sunday families was recognised in 2010 when several of the families proposed him for the Paul Foot Award for campaigning journalism. Their citation http://www.private-eye.co.uk/paul-foot-award/2010 said: "EAMONN McCANN has been using his journalism to campaign for justice for the Bloody Sunday families for almost 40 years. The publication of the Saville Report in June marked a victory for the families, a victory of which McCann was very much a part. In February 1972, within a month of the killings, McCann published the first pamphlet on Bloody Sunday, “What happened in Derry”. Throughout the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s he wrote about the injustice of Bloody Sunday whenever he got the opportunity. In the run-up to 1992, the 20th anniversary of the massacre, McCann made a proposal to the families for a book to mark the occasion. The publication of Bloody Sunday in Derry: What Really Happened was crucial in helping to bring together all the Bloody Sunday families for the first time into a single campaign. Throughout the 1990s McCann wrote constantly about Bloody Sunday, ensuring that every new piece of evidence about what had happened on the day and in the course of the subsequent cover-up was analysed and publicised. He wrote in the local Derry papers, in the Belfast Telegraph, the Irish Times, the Sunday Tribune, in the London Independent, the Guardian, the Observer – anywhere he could place a story. With the announcement of the Saville Tribunal, McCann's writing on Bloody Sunday came into its own. While other journalists focused only on the evidence of the more high-profile witnesses, McCann attended almost every day of the tribunal. He attended the hearings in London's Central Hall, paying his own costs to travel to and from London and staying with family while there. He wrote a weekly analysis for the Sunday Tribune in Dublin, and covered the proceedings daily for the Irish commercial radio station Today FM, as well as contributing articles to the Guardian, Observer, Irish Times, Irish Mirror and Irish Daily Mail." ==Writings and media work== {{Listen|filename=Eamonn McCann BBC Radio4 The Media Show 16 June 2010 b00sp5cf.flac|title=McCann's voice|type=speech|description=from the BBC programme ''[[The Media Show]]'', 16 June 2010{{cite episode|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00sp5cf|title=16 June 2010|series=The Media Show|serieslink=The Media Show|station=[[BBC Radio 4]]|date=16 June 2010|accessdate=16 June 2010}}}} McCann currently writes for the ''[[Belfast Telegraph]]'', ''[[The Irish Times]]'' and the ''[[Derry Journal]]''. He has written a column for the [[Dublin]]-based magazine, ''[[Hot Press]]'', and is a frequent commentator on the [[BBC]], [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]] and other broadcast media. He worked as a journalist for the ''[[Sunday World]]'' newspaper and contributed to the original ''In Dublin'' magazine, among others.{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/editorial/eamonn-mccann-7.2705731|title=Eamonn McCann|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=7 May 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/opinion/columnists/eamonn-mccann/|title=Eamonn McCann|work=[[Belfast Telegraph]]|accessdate=7 May 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.hotpress.com/Eamonn-McCann/news/Hot-Press-columnist-Eamonn-McCann-elected-to-Stormont/17226995.html|title=Hot Press columnist Eamonn McCann elected to Stormont|work=[[Hot Press]]|date=7 May 2016}} Much of his journalistic work reflects what he himself describes''Dear God: The Price of Religion in Ireland'' (Paperback) by Eamonn McCann, Bookmarks (10 November 1999); {{ISBN|1-898876-58-4}}; {{ISBN|978-1-898876-58-8}} as a "shuddering fascination" with religion which, when coupled with his profound skepticism, has made it a topic to which he has often returned.{{cite web|url=http://www.hotpress.com/archive/archives.php?author=2010155|title=Archives|work=[[Hot Press]]|accessdate=7 May 2016}} In March 2008, McCann spoke with [[National Public Radio]] in the U.S. about the solidarity between the Catholic civil rights movement in Northern Ireland and the [[Civil Rights Movement]] in the U.S.{{cite web|first=Drew|last=Tweksbury|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/newsandviews/2008/03/n_ireland_and_the_us_shared_ci.html|title=N. Ireland and the U.S.: A Shared Civil Rights Struggle|publisher=[[National Public Radio]]|date=17 March 2008|accessdate=17 March 2008}} In March 2014, following [[Crimean status referendum, 2014|Crimea's referendum on joining Russia]], McCann had a piece published in ''[[The Irish Times]]'' on the situation there. He commented: "After six years in office, Obama believes he has a right to invade anywhere, bomb anything, kill anybody whose jib the CIA doesn't like the cut of, irrespective of national or international law or, indeed, of the provisions of the US constitution. And now he lectures Putin on the necessity of 'respecting international law'. He has a nerve." In the same piece he wrote: "[[Vladimir Putin]] may run a vicious regime but the people of Crimea have a right to be accepted as Russian if that's what they want, which evidently they do",{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/if-we-have-to-pick-a-side-over-crimea-let-it-be-russia-1.1731105|title=If we have to pick a side over Crimea, let it be Russia|work=[[The Irish Times]]|date=20 March 2014|accessdate=2 January 2016}} and added: "Putin is right that the main motivation of the US and Nato has been to encircle and enfeeble his country. It might be a close run thing, but in this instance Russia has more right on its side than the West". ;List of works * ''War and an Irish Town'' (1973) * ''War and Peace in Northern Ireland'' * ''Dear God – The Price of Religion in Ireland'' He has also edited two books on Bloody Sunday: * ''Bloody Sunday: What Really Happened'' (1992) * ''The Bloody Sunday Inquiry: The Families Speak Out'' (2005). ==Personal life== McCann was the partner of [[Mary Holland]] (1935–2004), a journalist who worked for ''[[The Observer]]'' and ''[[The Irish Times]]''. He has a daughter from that relationship, Kitty, who is now a journalist for ''The Irish Times'', and a son, Luke, who works for the US-based human rights think tank The Center for Economic and Social Rights (www.cesr.org). The academic and activist [[Goretti Horgan]] has been his partner since the mid-1980s and they have an adult daughter, Matty.{{cite web|url=http://www.eamonnmccann.com/biography.html|title=Biography|publisher=Eamonn McCann|accessdate=7 May 2016}} McCann is a supporter of [[Derry City F.C.|Derry City Football Club]].Mahon, Eddie (1998), ''Derry City'', Guildhall Press, p. 83. In the 2002 film ''[[Bloody Sunday (film)|Bloody Sunday]]'', McCann was played by Irish actor Gerard Crossan.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0280491|title=''Bloody Sunday'' (film details)|work=[[IMDb]]|accessdate=2 January 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.eamonnmccann.com/}} *[https://www.marxists.org/history/etol/writers/mccann/index.htm Eamonn McCann Internet Archive] {{s-start}} {{s-par|ni/ass}} {{s-bef | before = [[Gerard Diver]] }} {{s-ttl | title = [[Member of the Legislative Assembly (Northern Ireland)|MLA]] for [[Foyle (Assembly constituency)|Foyle]] | years = 2016–2017 }} {{s-non | reason = Seat abolished }} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McCann, Eamonn}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century Irish people]] [[Category:21st-century Irish people]] [[Category:Alumni of Queen's University Belfast]] [[Category:Hot Press people]] [[Category:Irish anti-war activists]] [[Category:Irish social commentators]] [[Category:Irish anti-capitalists]] [[Category:Irish political writers]] [[Category:Irish Trotskyists]] [[Category:Irish activists]] [[Category:Irish political theorists]] [[Category:Journalists from Northern Ireland]] [[Category:LGBT rights activists from Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Marxist journalists]] [[Category:Non-fiction writers from Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Northern Ireland MLAs 2016–17]] [[Category:People Before Profit Alliance MLAs]] [[Category:People educated at St Columb's College]] [[Category:Politicians from Derry (city)]] [[Category:The Irish Times people]] [[Category:Socialists from Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Male writers from Northern Ireland]] [[Category:21st-century writers from Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Columnists from Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Critics of the European Union]] [[Category:Opinion journalists]]

revision.comment: /* Parkinson's disease */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Neurobiology of disease → Neurobiology of Disease
revision.text:
{{distinguish|Behavioral enrichment}} [[File:Rat coming out cage.jpg|thumb|300px| A rodent is not stimulated by the environment in a wire cage, and this affects its brain negatively, particularly the complexity of its synaptic connections]] '''Environmental enrichment''' is the stimulation of the [[brain]] by its physical and social surroundings. Brains in richer, more stimulating environments have higher rates of [[synaptogenesis]] and more complex [[dendrites|dendrite arbors]], leading to increased brain activity. This effect takes place primarily during [[neurodevelopment]], but also during adulthood to a lesser degree. With extra [[synapses]] there is also increased synapse activity, leading to an increased size and number of [[glia]]l energy-support cells. Environmental enrichment also enhances [[capillary]] vasculation, providing the neurons and glial cells with extra energy. The [[neuropil]] (neurons, glial cells, capillaries, combined together) expands, thickening the cortex. Research on rodent brains suggests that environmental enrichment may also lead to an increased rate of [[neurogenesis]].
Research on animals finds that environmental enrichment could aid the treatment and recovery of numerous brain-related dysfunctions, including [[Alzheimer's disease]] and those connected to [[aging]], whereas a lack of stimulation might impair cognitive development. Moreover, this research also suggests that environmental enrichment leads to a greater level of [[cognitive reserve]], the brain's resilience to the effects of conditions such as [[aging]] and [[dementia]].
Research on humans suggests that lack of stimulation delays and impairs cognitive development. Research also finds that attaining and engaging in higher levels of education, environments in which people participate in more challenging cognitively stimulating activities, results in greater cognitive reserve.
== Early research == [[Donald O. Hebb]] in 1947 found that rats raised as pets performed better on problem solving tests than rats raised in cages.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Hebb DO | title = The effects of early experience on problem solving at maturity | journal = American Psychologist | volume = 2 | pages = 306–7 | year = 1947 | doi = 10.1037/h0063667 }}</ref> His research, however, did not investigate the brain nor use standardized impoverished and enriched environments. Research doing this first was started in 1960 at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] by [[Mark Rosenzweig (psychologist)|Mark Rosenzweig]], who compared single rats in normal cages, and those placed in ones with toys, ladders, tunnels, running wheels in groups. This found that growing up in enriched environments affected enzyme [[cholinesterase]] activity.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/h0045402 |vauthors=Krech D, Rosenzweig MR, Bennett EL | title = Effects of environmental complexity and training on brain chemistry | journal = J Comp Physiol Psychol | volume = 53 | pages = 509–19 |date=December 1960 | pmid = 13754181 | issue = 6 }}</ref> This work led in 1962 to the discovery that environmental enrichment increased [[cerebral cortex]] volume.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/h0041137 |vauthors=Rosenzweig MR, Krech D, Bennett EL, Diamond MC | title = Effects of environmental complexity and training on brain chemistry and anatomy: a replication and extension | journal = J Comp Physiol Psychol | volume = 55 | pages = 429–37 |date=August 1962 | pmid = 14494091 | issue = 4 }}</ref> In 1964, it was found that this was due to increased cerebral cortex thickness and greater [[synapse]] and [[glial]] numbers.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1038/2041161a0 |vauthors=Altman J, Das GD | title = Autoradiographic Examination of the Effects of Enriched Environment on the Rate of Glial Multiplication in the Adult Rat Brain | journal = Nature | volume = 204 | pages = 1161–3 |date=December 1964 | pmid = 14264369 | issue = 4964 }}</ref><ref name="DiamondKrech">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1002/cne.901230110 |vauthors=Diamond MC, Krech D, Rosenzweig MR | title = The Effects of an Enriched Environment on the Histology of the Rat Cerebral Cortex | journal = J. Comp. Neurol. | volume = 123 | pages = 111–20 |date=August 1964 | pmid = 14199261 }}</ref>
Also starting around 1960, [[Harry Harlow]] studied the effects of [[maternal deprivation|maternal and social deprivation]] on [[rhesus monkey]] infants (a form of environmental stimulus deprivation). This established the importance of social stimulation for normal [[cognitive development|cognitive]] and emotional development.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Harlow HF, Rowland GL, Griffin GA | title = The Effect of Total Social Deprivation on the Development of Monkey Behavior | journal = Psychiatr Res Rep Am Psychiatr Assoc | volume = 19 | pages = 116–35 |date=December 1964 | pmid = 14232649 }}</ref>
== Synapses ==
=== Synaptogenesis ===
Rats raised with environmental enrichment have thicker cerebral cortices (3.3–7%) that contain 25% more [[synapses]].<ref name="DiamondKrech" /><ref name="DiamondLaw">{{cite journal |vauthors=Diamond MC, Law F, Rhodes H | title = Increases in cortical depth and glia numbers in rats subjected to enriched environment | journal = J. Comp. Neurol. | volume = 128 | issue = 1 | pages = 117–26 |date=September 1966 | pmid = 4165855 | doi = 10.1002/cne.901280110 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> This effect of environmental richness upon the brain occurs whether it is experienced immediately following birth,<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1126/science.167.3916.292 |vauthors=Schapiro S, Vukovich KR | title = Early experience effects upon cortical dendrites: a proposed model for development | journal = Science | volume = 167 | issue = 3916 | pages = 292–4 |date=January 1970 | pmid = 4188192 | url = http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=4188192 }}</ref> after weaning,<ref name="DiamondKrech" /><ref name="DiamondLaw" /><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Bennett EL, Diamond MC, Krech D, Rosenzweig MR | title = Chemical and Anatomical Plasticity Brain | journal = Science | volume = 146 | pages = 610–9 |date=October 1964 | pmid = 14191699 | url = http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=14191699 | doi = 10.1126/science.146.3644.610 | issue = 3644 }}</ref> or during maturity.<ref name="Briones" >{{cite journal |vauthors=Briones TL, Klintsova AY, Greenough WT | title = Stability of synaptic plasticity in the adult rat visual cortex induced by complex environment exposure | journal = Brain Res. | volume = 1018 | issue = 1 | pages = 130–5 |date=August 2004 | pmid = 15262214 | doi = 10.1016/j.brainres.2004.06.001 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0006899304009370 }}</ref> When synapse numbers increase in adults, they can remain high in number even when the adults are returned to impoverished environment for 30 days<ref name="Briones" /> suggesting that such increases in synapse numbers are not necessarily temporary. However, the increase in synapse numbers has been observed generally to reduce with maturation.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Holtmaat AJ, Trachtenberg JT, Wilbrecht L | title = Transient and persistent dendritic spines in the neocortex in vivo | journal = Neuron | volume = 45 | issue = 2 | pages = 279–91 |date=January 2005 | pmid = 15664179 | doi = 10.1016/j.neuron.2005.01.003 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0896627305000048 |display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Zuo Y, Lin A, Chang P, Gan WB | title = Development of long-term dendritic brain stability in diverse regions of cerebral cortex | journal = Neuron | volume = 46 | issue = 2 | pages = 181–9 |date=April 2005 | pmid = 15848798 | doi = 10.1016/j.neuron.2005.04.001 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0896-6273(05)00309-0 }}</ref> Stimulation affects not only synapses upon [[pyramidal neuron]]s (the main projecting neurons in the cerebral cortex) but also [[stellate cell|stellate]] ones (that are usually [[interneurons]]).<ref name="Greenough">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0014-4886(73)90090-3 |vauthors=Greenough WT, Volkmar FR | title = Pattern of dendritic branching in occipital cortex of rats reared in complex environments | journal = Exp. Neurol. | volume = 40 | issue = 2 | pages = 491–504 |date=August 1973 | pmid = 4730268 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0014-4886(73)90090-3 }}</ref> It also can affect neurons outside the brain in the [[retina]].<ref name="Landi, S. 2007">{{cite journal |vauthors=Landi S, Sale A, Berardi N, Viegi A, Maffei L, Cenni MC | title = Retinal functional development is sensitive to environmental enrichment: a role for BDNF | journal = FASEB J. | volume = 21 | issue = 1 | pages = 130–9 |date=January 2007 | pmid = 17135370 | doi = 10.1096/fj.06-6083com | url = http://www.fasebj.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17135370 }}</ref>
=== Dendrite complexity === Environmental enrichment affects the complexity and length of the [[dendrite]] arbors (upon which synapses form). Higher-order dendrite branch complexity is increased in enriched environments,<ref name="Greenough" /><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1126/science.176.4042.1445 |vauthors=Volkmar FR, Greenough WT | title = Rearing complexity affects branching of dendrites in the visual cortex of the rat | journal = Science | volume = 176 | issue = 4042 | pages = 1445–7 |date=June 1972 | pmid = 5033647 | url = http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=5033647 }}</ref> as can the length, in young animals, of distal branches.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0163-1047(92)90937-Y |vauthors=Wallace CS, Kilman VL, Withers GS, Greenough WT | title = Increases in dendritic length in occipital cortex after 4 days of differential housing in weanling rats | journal = Behav. Neural Biol. | volume = 58 | issue = 1 | pages = 64–8 |date=July 1992 | pmid = 1417672 }}</ref>
=== Activity and energy consumption === Synapses in animals in enriched environments show evidence of increased synapse activation.<ref name="Sirevaag">{{cite journal |vauthors=Sirevaag AM, Greenough WT | title = Differential rearing effects on rat visual cortex synapses. III. Neuronal and glial nuclei, boutons, dendrites, and capillaries | journal = Brain Res. | volume = 424 | issue = 2 | pages = 320–32 |date=October 1987 | pmid = 3676831 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0006-8993(87)91477-6 | doi = 10.1016/0006-8993(87)91477-6}}</ref> Synapses tend to also be much larger.<ref name="sievaag85">{{cite journal |vauthors=Sirevaag AM, Greenough WT | title = Differential rearing effects on rat visual cortex synapses. II. Synaptic morphometry | journal = Brain Res. | volume = 351 | issue = 2 | pages = 215–26 |date=April 1985 | pmid = 3995348 | doi = 10.1016/0165-3806(85)90193-2}}</ref> [[Gamma wave|Gamma oscillations]] become larger in amplitude in the hippocampus.<ref name="Shinohara">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1038/ncomms2658 |vauthors=Shinohara Y, Hosoya A, Hirase H | title = Experience enhances gamma oscillations and interhemispheric asymmetry in the hippocampus | journal = Nat Commun | volume = 4 | pages = 1652 |date=April 2013 | pmid = 23552067 | url = http://www.nature.com/ncomms/journal/v4/n4/full/ncomms2658.html | issue=4 | pmc=3644069}}</ref> This increased energy consumption is reflected in glial and local capillary vasculation that provides synapses with extra energy. * Glial cell numbers per neuron increase 12–14%<ref name="DiamondKrech" /><ref name="DiamondLaw" /> * The direct apposition area of glial cells with synapses expands by 19%<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Jones TA, Greenough WT | title = Ultrastructural evidence for increased contact between astrocytes and synapses in rats reared in a complex environment | journal = Neurobiol Learn Mem | volume = 65 | issue = 1 | pages = 48–56 |date=January 1996 | pmid = 8673406 | doi = 10.1006/nlme.1996.0005 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1074-7427(96)90005-2 }}</ref> * The volume of glial cell nuclei for each synapse is higher by 37.5%<ref name="Sirevaag" /> * The mean volume of mitochondria per neuron is 20% greater<ref name="Sirevaag" /> * The volume of glial cell nuclei for each neuron is 63% higher<ref name="Sirevaag" /> * Capillary density is increased.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Borowsky IW, Collins RC | title = Metabolic anatomy of brain: a comparison of regional capillary density, glucose metabolism, and enzyme activities | journal = J. Comp. Neurol. | volume = 288 | issue = 3 | pages = 401–13 |date=October 1989 | pmid = 2551935 | doi = 10.1002/cne.902880304 }}</ref> * Capillaries are wider (4.35 μm compared to 4.15 μm in controls)<ref name="Sirevaag" /> * Shorter distance exist between any part of the [[neuropil]] and a capillary (27.6 μm compared to 34.6 μm)<ref name="Sirevaag" /> These energy related changes to the [[neuropil]] are responsible for increasing the volume of the cerebral cortex (the increase in synapse numbers contributes in itself hardly any extra volume).
=== Motor learning stimulation === Part of the effect of environmental enrichment is providing opportunities to acquire [[motor skills]]. Research upon “acrobatic” skill learning in the rat shows that it leads to increased synapse numbers.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1073/pnas.87.14.5568 |vauthors=Black JE, Isaacs KR, Anderson BJ, Alcantara AA, Greenough WT | title = Learning causes synaptogenesis, whereas motor activity causes angiogenesis, in cerebellar cortex of adult rats | journal = Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. | volume = 87 | issue = 14 | pages = 5568–72 |date=July 1990 | pmid = 1695380 | pmc = 54366 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kleim JA, Hogg TM, VandenBerg PM, Cooper NR, Bruneau R, Remple M | title = Cortical synaptogenesis and motor map reorganization occur during late, but not early, phase of motor skill learning | journal = J. Neurosci. | volume = 24 | issue = 3 | pages = 628–33 |date=January 2004 | pmid = 14736848 | doi = 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.3440-03.2004 | url = http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=14736848 }}</ref>
=== Maternal transmission === Environmental enrichment during [[pregnancy]] has effects upon the [[fetus]] such as accelerating its retinal development.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Sale A, Cenni MC, Ciucci F, Putignano E, Chierzi S, Maffei L | title = Maternal Enrichment during Pregnancy Accelerates Retinal Development of the Fetus | journal = PLoS ONE | volume = 2 | issue = 11 | pages = e1160 | year = 2007 | pmid = 18000533 | pmc = 2063464 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0001160 | url = http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0001160 | editor1-last = Reh | editor1-first = Thomas }} {{open access}}</ref>
== Neurogenesis == Environmental enrichment can also lead to the [[neurogenesis|formation of neurons]] (at least in rats)<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Fan Y, Liu Z, Weinstein PR, Fike JR, Liu J | title = Environmental enrichment enhances neurogenesis and improves functional outcome after cranial irradiation | journal = Eur. J. Neurosci. | volume = 25 | issue = 1 | pages = 38–46 |date=January 2007 | pmid = 17241265 | doi = 10.1111/j.1460-9568.2006.05269.x }}</ref> and reverses the loss of neurons in the [[hippocampus]] and memory impairment following chronic stress.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Veena J, Srikumar BN, Mahati K, Bhagya V, Raju TR, Shankaranarayana Rao BS | title = Enriched environment restores hippocampal cell proliferation and ameliorates cognitive deficits in chronically stressed rats | journal = J. Neurosci. Res. | volume = 87 | issue = 4 | pages = 831–43 |date=March 2009 | pmid = 19006089 | doi = 10.1002/jnr.21907 }}</ref> However, its relevance has been questioned for the behavioral effects of enriched environments.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Meshi D, Drew MR, Saxe M | title = Hippocampal neurogenesis is not required for behavioral effects of environmental enrichment | journal = Nat. Neurosci. | volume = 9 | issue = 6 | pages = 729–31 |date=June 2006 | pmid = 16648847 | doi = 10.1038/nn1696 |display-authors=etal}}</ref>
== Mechanisms ==
Enriched environments affect the expression of [[genes]] in the cerebral cortex and the hippocampus that determine neuronal structure.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Rampon C, Jiang CH, Dong H | title = Effects of environmental enrichment on gene expression in the brain | journal = Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. | volume = 97 | issue = 23 | pages = 12880–4 |date=November 2000 | pmid = 11070096 | pmc = 18858 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.97.23.12880 | url = http://www.pnas.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=11070096 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> At the molecular level, this occurs through increased concentrations of the [[neurotrophins]] [[Nerve growth factor|NGF]], [[NT-3]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ickes BR, Pham TM, Sanders LA, Albeck DS, Mohammed AH, Granholm AC | title = Long-term environmental enrichment leads to regional increases in neurotrophin levels in rat brain | journal = Exp. Neurol. | volume = 164 | issue = 1 | pages = 45–52 |date=July 2000 | pmid = 10877914 | doi = 10.1006/exnr.2000.7415 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0014-4886(00)97415-6 }}</ref><ref name="Torasdotter, M. 1998">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0166-4328(97)00142-3 |vauthors=Torasdotter M, Metsis M, Henriksson BG, Winblad B, Mohammed AH | title = Environmental enrichment results in higher levels of nerve growth factor mRNA in the rat visual cortex and hippocampus | journal = Behav. Brain Res. | volume = 93 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 83–90 |date=June 1998 | pmid = 9659990 }}</ref> and changes in [[BDNF]].<ref name="Landi, S. 2007" /><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Zhu SW, Codita A, Bogdanovic N | title = Influence of environmental manipulation on exploratory behaviour in male BDNF knockout mice | journal = Behav. Brain Res. | volume = 197 | issue = 2 | pages = 339–46 |date=February 2009 | pmid = 18951926 | doi = 10.1016/j.bbr.2008.09.032 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0166-4328(08)00529-9 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> This alters the activation of [[cholinergic]] neurons,<ref name="Torasdotter, M. 1998" /> [[5-HT]],<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0169-328X(97)00317-3 |vauthors=Rasmuson S, Olsson T, Henriksson BG | title = Environmental enrichment selectively increases 5-HT1A receptor mRNA expression and binding in the rat hippocampus | journal = Brain Res. Mol. Brain Res. | volume = 53 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 285–90 |date=January 1998 | pmid = 9473697 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> and [[Adrenergic receptor|beta-adrenolin]].<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1006/nlme.1995.1043 |vauthors=Escorihuela RM, Fernández-Teruel A, Tobeña A | title = Early environmental stimulation produces long-lasting changes on beta-adrenoceptor transduction system | journal = Neurobiol Learn Mem | volume = 64 | issue = 1 | pages = 49–57 |date=July 1995 | pmid = 7582812 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S107474278571043X |display-authors=etal}}</ref> Another effect is to increase proteins such as [[synaptophysin]] and [[DLG4|PSD-95]] in synapses.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Nithianantharajah J, Levis H, Murphy M | title = Environmental enrichment results in cortical and subcortical changes in levels of synaptophysin and PSD-95 proteins | journal = Neurobiol Learn Mem | volume = 81 | issue = 3 | pages = 200–10 |date=May 2004 | pmid = 15082021 | doi = 10.1016/j.nlm.2004.02.002 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1074742704000206 }}</ref> Changes in [[Wnt signaling pathway|Wnt signaling]] have also been found to mimic in adult mice the effects of environmental enrichment upon synapses in the hippocampus.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Gogolla N, Galimberti I, Deguchi Y, Caroni P | title = Wnt signaling mediates experience-related regulation of synapse numbers and mossy fiber connectivities in the adult hippocampus | journal = Neuron | volume = 62 | issue = 4 | pages = 510–25 |date=May 2009 | pmid = 19477153 | doi = 10.1016/j.neuron.2009.04.022 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0896-6273(09)00346-8 }}</ref> Increase in neurons numbers could be linked to changes in [[Vascular endothelial growth factor|VEGF]].<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.2174/156720506775697133 |vauthors=During MJ, Cao L | title = VEGF, a mediator of the effect of experience on hippocampal neurogenesis | journal = Curr Alzheimer Res | volume = 3 | issue = 1 | pages = 29–33 |date=February 2006 | pmid = 16472200 | url = http://www.bentham-direct.org/pages/content.php?CAR/2006/00000003/00000001/007AT.SGM }}</ref>
== Rehabilitation and resilience ==
Research in animals suggests that environmental enrichment aids in recovery from an array of neurological disorders and cognitive impairments. There are two mains areas of focus: neurological rehabilitation and [[cognitive reserve]], the brain's resistance to the effects of exposure to physical, natural, and social threats. Although most of these experiments used animal subjects, mainly rodents, researchers have pointed to the affected areas of animal brains to which human brains are most similar and used their findings as evidence to show that humans would have comparable reactions to enriched environments. The tests done on animals are thus meant to represent human simulations for the following list of conditions.
===Neurological rehabilitation===
====Autism====
A study conducted in 2011 led to the conclusion that environmental enrichment vastly improves the cognitive ability of children with [[autism]]. The study found that autistic children who receive olfactory and tactile stimulation along with exercises that stimulated other paried sensory modalities clinically improved by 42 percent while autistic children not receiving this treatment clinically improved by just 7 percent.<ref name = Woo>{{cite journal |vauthors=Woo CC, Leon M |title=Environmental Enrichment as an Effective Treatment for Autism: A Randomized Controlled Trial |journal=Behav Neurosci |volume=127 |issue=4 |pages=487–97 |date=March 2011 |pmid=23688137 |doi=10.1037/a0033010 }}</ref> The same study also showed that there was significant clinical improvement in autistic children exposed to enriched sensorimotor environments, and a vast majority of parents reported that their child's quality of life was much better with the treatment.<ref name = Woo/> A second study confirmed its effectiveness. The second study also found after 6 months of sensory enrichment therapy, 21% of the children who initially had been given an autism classification, using the Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule, improved to the point that, although they remained on the autism spectrum, they no longer met the criteria for classic autism. None of the standard care controls reached an equivalent level of improvement.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Woo, Cynthia C. |author2=Donnelly, Joseph H. |author3=Steinberg-Epstein, Robin |author4=Leon, Michael | title=Environmental enrichment as a therapy for autism: A clinical trial replication and extension |journal=Behavioral Neuroscience |pages= 412–422|date=Aug 2015 |pmid= 26052790|doi=10.1037/bne0000068 |volume=129 |issue=4 |pmc=4682896}}</ref> The therapy using the methodologies is titled Sensory Enrichment Therapy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webmd.com/brain/autism/news/20130605/sensory-focused-autism-therapy-shows-early-promise |title='Sensory-Focused' Autism Therapy Shows Early Promise |author=Mary Brophy Marcus |date=June 5, 2013 |website=webmd.com |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ksl.com/?sid=31896222&nid=148&title=autism-treatment-gives-utah-family-hope |title=Autism treatment gives Utah family hope |author=Nkoyo Iyamba |date=October 9, 2014 |website=ksl.com |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref>
====Alzheimer's disease====
Through environmental enrichment, researchers were able to enhance and partially repair memory deficits in mice between ages of 2 to 7 months with characteristics of [[Alzheimer's disease]]. Mice in enriched environments performed significantly better on object recognition tests and the [[Morris water navigation task|Morris Water Maze]] than they had when they were in standard environments. It was thus concluded that environmental enrichment enhances visual and learning memory for those with Alzheimer's.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Berardi N, Braschi C, Capsoni S, Cattaneo A, Maffei L |title=Environmental enrichment delays the onset of memory deficits and reduces neuropathological hallmarks in a mouse model of Alzheimer-like neurodegeneration |journal=J. Alzheimers Dis. |volume=11 |issue=3 |pages=359–70 |date=June 2007 |pmid=17851186 |url=http://iospress.metapress.com/openurl.asp?genre=article&issn=1387-2877&volume=11&issue=3&spage=359 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Furthermore, it has been found that mouse models of Alzheimer's disease that were exposed to enriched environment before amyloid onset (at 3 months of age) and then returned to their home cage for over 7 months, showed preserved spatial memory and reduced amyloid deposition at 13 months old, when they are supposed to show dramatic memory deficits and amyloid plaque load. These findings reveal the preventive, and long-lasting effects of early life stimulating experience on Alzheimer-like pathology in mice and likely reflect the capacity of enriched environment to efficiently stimulate the [[cognitive reserve]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Verret L, Krezymon A, Halley H, Trouche S, Zerwas M, Lazouret M, Lassalle JM, Rampon C | title = Transient enriched housing before amyloidosis onset sustains cognitive improvement in Tg2576 mice | journal = Neurobiology of Aging | volume = 34 | issue = 1 | pages = 211–25 |date=Jan 2013 | pmid = 22727275 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0197458012003004 | doi=10.1016/j.neurobiolaging.2012.05.013}}</ref>
====Huntington's disease====
Research has indicated that environmental enrichment can help relieve motor and psychiatric deficits caused by [[Huntington's disease]]. It also improves lost protein levels for those with the disease, and prevents striatal and hippocampal deficits in the BDNF, located in the hippocampus.<ref name = Spires>{{cite journal |vauthors=Spires TL, Grote HE, Varshney NK | title = Environmental enrichment rescues protein deficits in a mouse model of Huntington's disease, indicating a possible disease mechanism | journal = J. Neurosci. | volume = 24 | issue = 9 | pages = 2270–6 |date=March 2004 | pmid = 14999077 | doi = 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.1658-03.2004 | url = http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=14999077 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> These findings have led researchers to suggest that environmental enrichment has a potential to be a possible form of therapy for those with Huntington's.<ref name = Spires/>
====Parkinson's disease====
Multiple studies have reported that environmental enrichment for adult mice helps relieve neuronal death, which is particularly beneficial to those with [[Parkinson's disease]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Faherty CJ, Raviie Shepherd K, Herasimtschuk A, Smeyne RJ | title = Environmental enrichment in adulthood eliminates neuronal death in experimental Parkinsonism | journal = Brain Res. Mol. Brain Res. | volume = 134 | issue = 1 | pages = 170–9 |date=March 2005 | pmid = 15790541 | doi = 10.1016/j.molbrainres.2004.08.008 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0169-328X(04)00403-6 }}</ref> A more recent study shows that environmental enrichment particularly affects the [[nigrostriatal pathway]], which is important for managing [[dopamine]] and acetylcholine levels, critical for motor deficits.<ref name = Goldberg>{{cite journal|last=Goldberg|first=NR|author2=Fields, V |author3=Pflibsen, L |author4=Salvatore, MF |author5= Meshul, CK |title=Social enrichment attenuates nigrostriatal lesioning and reverses motor impairment in a progressive 1-methyl-2-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine (MPTP) mouse model of Parkinson's disease.|journal=Neurobiology of Disease|date=March 2012|volume=45|issue=3|pages=1051–67|pmid=22198503|doi=10.1016/j.nbd.2011.12.024}}</ref> Moreover, it was found that environmental enrichment has beneficial effects for the social implications of Parkinson's disease.<ref name = Goldberg/>
====Stroke====
Research done in animals has shown that subjects recovering in an enriched environment 15 days after having a [[stroke]] had significantly improved neurobehavioral function. In addition these same subjects showed greater capability of learning and larger infarct post-intervention than those who were not in an enriched environment. It was thus concluded that environmental enrichment had a considerable beneficial effect on the learning and sensorimotor functions on animals post-stroke.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Janssen H, Bernhardt J, Collier JM, Sena ES, McElduff P, Attia J, Pollack M, Howells DW, Nilsson M, Calford MB, Spratt NJ |title=An Enriched Environment Improves Sensorimotor Function Post-Ischemic Stroke|journal=Neurorehabilitation and Neural Repair|date=12 September 2010|volume=24|issue=9|pages=802–813|doi=10.1177/1545968310372092|pmid=20834046}}</ref> A 2013 study also found that environmental enrichment socially benefits patients recovering from stroke. Researchers in that study concluded that stroke patients in enriched environments in assisted-care facilities are much more likely to be engaging with other patients during normal social hours instead of being alone or sleeping.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Janssen|first=Heidi|author2=Ada, Louise |author3=Bernhardt, Julie |author4=McElduff, Patrick |author5=Pollack, Michael |author6=Nilsson, Michael |author7= Spratt, Neil J. |title=An enriched environment increases activity in stroke patients undergoing rehabilitation in a mixed rehabilitation unit: a pilot non-randomized controlled trial|journal=Disability and Rehabilitation|date=29 April 2013|pages=1–8|doi=10.3109/09638288.2013.788218|pmid=23627534 |volume=36 |issue=3}}</ref>
====Rett syndrome====
A 2008 study found that environmental enrichment was significant in aiding recovery of motor coordination and some recovery of BDNF levels in female mice with conditions similar to those of [[Rett syndrome]]. Over the course of 30 weeks female mice in enriched environments showed superior ability in motor coordination to those in standard conditions.<ref name = Kondo>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kondo M, Gray LJ, Pelka GJ, Christodoulou J, Tam PP, Hannan AJ | title = Environmental enrichment ameliorates a motor coordination deficit in a mouse model of Rett syndrome--Mecp2 gene dosage effects and BDNF expression | journal = Eur. J. Neurosci. | volume = 27 | issue = 12 | pages = 3342–50 |date=June 2008 | pmid = 18557922 | doi = 10.1111/j.1460-9568.2008.06305.x }}</ref> Although they were unable to have full motor capability, they were able to prevent a more severe motor deficit by living in an enriched environment. These results combined with increased levels of BDNF in the cerebellum led researchers to conclude that an enriched environment that stimulates areas of the motor cortex and areas of the cerebellum having to do with motor learning is beneficial in aiding mice with Rett syndrome.<ref name = Kondo/>
====Amblyopia====
A recent study found that adult rats with [[amblyopia]] improved visual acuity two weeks after being placed into an enriched environment.<ref name = Sale>{{cite journal |vauthors=Sale A, Maya Vetencourt JF, Medini P | title = Environmental enrichment in adulthood promotes amblyopia recovery through a reduction of intracortical inhibition | journal = Nat. Neurosci. | volume = 10 | issue = 6 | pages = 679–81 |date=June 2007 | pmid = 17468749 | doi = 10.1038/nn1899 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> The same study showed that another two weeks after ending environmental enrichment, the rats retained their visual acuity improvement. Conversely, rats in a standard environment showed no improvement in visual acuity. It was thus concluded that environmental enrichment reduces GABA inhibition and increases BDNF expression in the visual cortex. As a result, the growth and development of neurons and synapses in the visual cortex were much improved due to the enriched environment.<ref name = Sale/>
====Sensory deprivation====
Studies have shown that with the help of environmental enrichment the effects of [[sensory deprivation]] can be corrected. For example, a visual impairment known as "dark-rearing" in the visual cortex can be prevented and rehabilitated. In general, an enriched environment will improve, if not repair, the sensory systems animals possess.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-7580.2009.01103.x |vauthors=Argandoña EG, Bengoetxea H, Lafuente JV | title = Physical exercise is required for environmental enrichment to offset the quantitative effects of dark-rearing on the S-100β astrocytic density in the rat visual cortex | journal = Journal of Anatomy | volume = 215 | issue = 2 | pages = 132–140 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19500177 | pmc = 2740960 }}</ref>
====Lead poisoning====
During development, [[gestation]] is one of the most critical periods for exposure to any lead. Exposure to high levels of lead at this time can lead to inferior spatial learning performance. Studies have shown that environmental enrichment can overturn damage to the hippocampus induced by [[lead poisoning|lead exposure]].<ref name = Cao>{{cite journal|last=Cao|first=Xiujing|author2=Huang, Shenghai |author3=Ruan, Diyun |title=Enriched environment restores impaired hippocampal long-term potentiation and water maze performance induced by developmental lead exposure in rats|journal=Developmental Psychobiology|date=April 2008|volume=50|issue=3|pages=307–313|doi=10.1002/dev.20287|pmid=18335502}}</ref> Learning and spatial memory that are dependent on the long-term potentiation of the hippocampus are vastly improve as subjects in an enriched environments had lower levels of lead concentration in their hippocampi. The findings also showed that enriched environments result in some natural protection of lead-induced brain deficits.<ref name = Cao/>
====Chronic spinal cord injuries====
Research has indicated that animals suffering from [[spinal cord injuries]] showed significant improvement in motor capabilities even with a long delay in treatment after the injury when exposed to environmental enrichment.<ref name = Fischer>{{cite journal |vauthors=Fischer FR, Peduzzi JD | title = Functional Recovery in Rats With Chronic Spinal Cord Injuries After Exposure to an Enriched Environment | journal = J Spinal Cord Med | volume = 30 | issue = 2 | pages = 147–55 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17591227 | pmc = 2031947 }}</ref> Social interactions, exercise, and novelty all play major roles in aiding the recovery of an injured subject. This has led to some suggestions that the spinal cord has a continued plasticity and all efforts must be made for enriched environments to stimulate this plasticity in order to aid recovery.<ref name = Fischer/>
====Maternal deprivation stress====
[[Maternal deprivation]] can be caused by the abandonment by a nurturing parent at a young age. In rodents or nonhuman primates, this leads to a higher vulnerability for stress-related illness.<ref name = Francis>{{cite journal |vauthors=Francis DD, Diorio J, Plotsky PM, Meaney MJ | title = Environmental enrichment reverses the effects of maternal separation on stress reactivity | journal = J. Neurosci. | volume = 22 | issue = 18 | pages = 7840–3 |date=September 2002 | pmid = 12223535 | url = http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=12223535 }}</ref> Research suggests that environmental enrichment can reverse the effects of maternal separation on stress reactivity, possibly by affecting the hippocampus and the prefrontal cortex.<ref name = Francis/>
====Child neglect====
In all children, maternal care is one of the significant influences for hippocampal development, providing the foundation for stable and individualized learning and memory. However, this is not the case for those who have experienced [[child neglect]]. Researchers determined that through environmental enrichment, a neglected child can partially receive the same hippocampal development and stability, albeit not at the same level as that of the presence of a parent or guardian.<ref name = Bredy>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0306-4522(02)00918-1 |vauthors=Bredy TW, Humpartzoomian RA, Cain DP, Meaney MJ | title = Partial reversal of the effect of maternal care on cognitive function through environmental enrichment | journal = Neuroscience | volume = 118 | issue = 2 | pages = 571–6 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12699791 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0306452202009181 }}</ref> The results were comparable to those of child intervention programs, rendering environmental enrichment a useful method for dealing with child neglect.<ref name = Bredy/>{{failed verification|I do not have access to full article, but it describes a study with rats, in which the effects of being raised by mothers with low licking/grooming behavior were reversed through environmental enrichment at the behavioral level but not at the physiological level.|date=January 2014}}
=== Cognitive reserve ===
====Aging====
Decreased hippocampal neurogenesis is a characteristic of [[aging]]. Environmental enrichment increases neurogenesis in aged rodents by potentiating neuronal differentiation and new cell survival.<ref name = Kumar>{{cite journal|last=Speisman|first=RB|author2=Kumar, A |author3=Rani, A |author4=Pastoriza, JM |author5=Severance, JE |author6=Foster, TC |author7= Ormerod, BK |title=Environmental enrichment restores neurogenesis and rapid acquisition in aged rats.|journal=Neurobiology of Aging|date=January 2013|volume=34|issue=1|pages=263–74|pmid=22795793|doi=10.1016/j.neurobiolaging.2012.05.023 |pmc=3480541}}</ref> As a result, subjects exposed to environmental enrichment aged better due to superior ability in retaining their levels of spatial and learning memory.<ref name = Kumar/>
====Prenatal and perinatal cocaine exposure====
Research has shown that mice exposed to environmental enrichment are less affected by the consequences of [[Cocaine#Effects in pregnancy and nursing|cocaine exposure]] in comparison with those in standard environments. Although the levels of dopamine in the brains of both sets of mice were relatively similar, when both subjects were exposed to the cocaine injection, mice in enriched environment were significantly less responsive than those in standard environments.<ref name = Solinas>{{cite journal |vauthors=Solinas M, Thiriet N, El Rawas R, Lardeux V, Jaber M | title = Environmental enrichment during early stages of life reduces the behavioral, neurochemical, and molecular effects of cocaine | journal = Neuropsychopharmacology | volume = 34 | issue = 5 | pages = 1102–11 |date=April 2009 | pmid = 18463628 | doi = 10.1038/npp.2008.51 }}</ref> It was thus concluded that both the activating and rewarding effects are suppressed by environmental enrichment and early exposure to environmental enrichment can help prevent [[drug addiction]].<ref name = Solinas/>
== Humans ==
Though environmental enrichment research has been mostly done upon rodents, similar effects occur in primates,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kozorovitskiy Y, Gross CG, Kopil C | title = Experience induces structural and biochemical changes in the adult primate brain | journal = Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. | volume = 102 | issue = 48 | pages = 17478–82 |date=November 2005 | pmid = 16299105 | pmc = 1297690 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0508817102 | url = http://www.pnas.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=16299105 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> and are likely to affect the human brain. However, direct research upon human synapses and their numbers is limited since this requires [[histological]] study of the brain. A link, however, has been found between educational level and greater dendritic branch complexity following autopsy removal of the brain.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Jacobs B, Schall M, Scheibel AB | title = A quantitative dendritic analysis of Wernicke's area in humans. II. Gender, hemispheric, and environmental factors | journal = J. Comp. Neurol. | volume = 327 | issue = 1 | pages = 97–111 |date=January 1993 | pmid = 8432910 | doi = 10.1002/cne.903270108 }}</ref>
=== Localized cerebral cortex changes === MRI detects localized [[cerebral cortex]] expansion after people learn complex tasks such as mirror reading (in this case in the right [[occipital cortex]]),<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ilg R, Wohlschläger AM, Gaser C | title = Gray matter increase induced by practice correlates with task-specific activation: a combined functional and morphometric magnetic resonance imaging study | journal = J. Neurosci. | volume = 28 | issue = 16 | pages = 4210–5 |date=April 2008 | pmid = 18417700 | doi = 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.5722-07.2008 | url = http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=18417700 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> three-ball juggling (bilateral mid-[[Temporal lobe|temporal]] area and left posterior [[intraparietal sulcus]]),<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Draganski B, Gaser C, Busch V, Schuierer G, Bogdahn U, May A | title = Neuroplasticity: changes in grey matter induced by training | journal = Nature | volume = 427 | issue = 6972 | pages = 311–2 |date=January 2004 | pmid = 14737157 | doi = 10.1038/427311a }}</ref> and when medical students intensively revise for exams (bilaterally in the posterior and lateral [[parietal cortex]]).<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Draganski B, Gaser C, Kempermann G | title = Temporal and spatial dynamics of brain structure changes during extensive learning | journal = J. Neurosci. | volume = 26 | issue = 23 | pages = 6314–7 |date=June 2006 | pmid = 16763039 | doi = 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.4628-05.2006 | url = http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=16763039 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> Such changes in gray matter volume can be expected to link to changes in synapse numbers due to the increased numbers of glial cells and the expanded capillary vascularization needed to support their increased energy consumption.
=== Institutional deprivation === Children that receive impoverished stimulation due to being confined to cots without social interaction or reliable caretakers in low quality [[orphanages]] show severe delays in cognitive and social development.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-7610.1994.tb01220.x |vauthors=Kaler SR, Freeman BJ | title = Analysis of environmental deprivation: cognitive and social development in Romanian orphans | journal = J Child Psychol Psychiatry | volume = 35 | issue = 4 | pages = 769–81 |date=May 1994 | pmid = 7518826 }}</ref> 12% of them if adopted after 6 months of age show autistic or mildly autistic traits later at four years of age.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Rutter M, Andersen-Wood L, Beckett C | title = Quasi-autistic patterns following severe early global privation. English and Romanian Adoptees (ERA) Study Team | journal = J Child Psychol Psychiatry | volume = 40 | issue = 4 | pages = 537–49 |date=May 1999 | pmid = 10357161 | doi = 10.1017/S0021963099003935 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> Some children in such impoverished orphanages at two and half years of age still fail to produce intelligible words, though a year of foster care enabled such children to catch up in their language in most respects.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Windsor J, Glaze LE, Koga SF | title = Language acquisition with limited input: Romanian institution and foster care | journal = J. Speech Lang. Hear. Res. | volume = 50 | issue = 5 | pages = 1365–81 |date=October 2007 | pmid = 17905917 | doi = 10.1044/1092-4388(2007/095) }}</ref> Catch-up in other cognitive functioning also occurs after adoption, though problems continue in many children if this happens after the age of 6 months<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Beckett C, Maughan B, Rutter M | title = Do the effects of early severe deprivation on cognition persist into early adolescence? Findings from the English and Romanian adoptees study | journal = Child Dev | volume = 77 | issue = 3 | pages = 696–711 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16686796 | doi = 10.1111/j.1467-8624.2006.00898.x |display-authors=etal}}</ref>
Such children show marked differences in their brains, consistent with research upon experiment animals, compared to children from normally stimulating environments. They have reduced brain activity in the [[Orbitofrontal cortex|orbital prefrontal cortex]], [[amygdala]], [[hippocampus]], [[temporal cortex]], and [[brain stem]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Chugani HT, Behen ME, Muzik O, Juhász C, Nagy F, Chugani DC | title = Local brain functional activity following early deprivation: a study of postinstitutionalized Romanian orphans | journal = NeuroImage | volume = 14 | issue = 6 | pages = 1290–301 |date=December 2001 | pmid = 11707085 | doi = 10.1006/nimg.2001.0917 }}</ref> They also showed less developed [[white matter]] connections between different areas in their cerebral cortices, particularly the [[uncinate fasciculus]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Eluvathingal TJ, Chugani HT, Behen ME | title = Abnormal brain connectivity in children after early severe socioemotional deprivation: a diffusion tensor imaging study | journal = Pediatrics | volume = 117 | issue = 6 | pages = 2093–100 |date=June 2006 | pmid = 16740852 | doi = 10.1542/peds.2005-1727 |display-authors=etal}}</ref>
Conversely, enriching the experience of [[Premature birth|preterm infants]] with [[massage]] quickens the maturating of their [[EEG|electroencephalographic]] activity and their [[visual acuity]]. Moreover, as with enrichment in experimental animals, this associates with an increase in [[IGF-1]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Guzzetta A, Baldini S, Bancale A | title = Massage accelerates brain development and the maturation of visual function | journal = J. Neurosci. | volume = 29 | issue = 18 | pages = 6042–51 |date=May 2009 | pmid = 19420271 | doi = 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.5548-08.2009 | url = http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=19420271 |display-authors=etal}}</ref>
=== Cognitive reserve and resilience === Another source of evidence for the effect of environment stimulation upon the human brain is [[cognitive reserve]] (a measure of the brain’s resilience to cognitive impairment) and the level of a person’s education. Not only is higher education linked to a more cognitively demanding educational experience, but it also correlates with a person’s general engagement in cognitively demanding activities.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1076/jcen.25.5.634.14572 |vauthors=Wilson R, Barnes L, Bennett D | title = Assessment of lifetime participation in cognitively stimulating activities | journal = J Clin Exp Neuropsychol | volume = 25 | issue = 5 | pages = 634–42 |date=August 2003 | pmid = 12815501 }}</ref> The more education a person has received, the less the effects of aging,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Corral M, Rodríguez M, Amenedo E, Sánchez JL, Díaz F | title = Cognitive reserve, age, and neuropsychological performance in healthy participants | journal = Dev Neuropsychol | volume = 29 | issue = 3 | pages = 479–91 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16671863 | doi = 10.1207/s15326942dn2903_6 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Fritsch T, McClendon MJ, Smyth KA, Lerner AJ, Friedland RP, Larsen JD | title = Cognitive functioning in healthy aging: the role of reserve and lifestyle factors early in life | journal = Gerontologist | volume = 47 | issue = 3 | pages = 307–22 |date=June 2007 | pmid = 17565095 | doi = 10.1093/geront/47.3.307 }}</ref> dementia,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Hall CB, Derby C, LeValley A, Katz MJ, Verghese J, Lipton RB | title = Education delays accelerated decline on a memory test in persons who develop dementia | journal = Neurology | volume = 69 | issue = 17 | pages = 1657–64 |date=October 2007 | pmid = 17954781 | doi = 10.1212/01.wnl.0000278163.82636.30 }}</ref> white matter hyperintensities,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Nebes RD, Meltzer CC, Whyte EM | title = The relation of white matter hyperintensities to cognitive performance in the normal old: education matters | journal = Neuropsychol Dev Cogn B Aging Neuropsychol Cogn | volume = 13 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 326–40 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16887777 | doi = 10.1080/138255890969294 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> MRI-defined brain infarcts,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Elkins JS, Longstreth WT, Manolio TA, Newman AB, Bhadelia RA, Johnston SC | title = Education and the cognitive decline associated with MRI-defined brain infarct | journal = Neurology | volume = 67 | issue = 3 | pages = 435–40 |date=August 2006 | pmid = 16894104 | doi = 10.1212/01.wnl.0000228246.89109.98 }}</ref> Alzheimer's disease,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Koepsell TD, Kurland BF, Harel O, Johnson EA, Zhou XH, Kukull WA | title = Education, cognitive function, and severity of neuropathology in Alzheimer disease | journal = Neurology | volume = 70 | issue = 19 Pt 2 | pages = 1732–9 |date=May 2008 | pmid = 18160675 | doi = 10.1212/01.wnl.0000284603.85621.aa }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Roe CM, Mintun MA, D'Angelo G, Xiong C, Grant EA, Morris JC | title = Alzheimer's and Cognitive Reserve: Education Effect Varies with 11CPIB Uptake | journal = Arch. Neurol. | volume = 65 | issue = 11 | pages = 1467–71 |date=November 2008 | pmid = 19001165 | pmc = 2752218 | doi = 10.1001/archneur.65.11.1467 }}</ref> and traumatic brain injury.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1207/S15324826AN1003_04 |vauthors=Kesler SR, Adams HF, Blasey CM, Bigler ED | title = Premorbid intellectual functioning, education, and brain size in traumatic brain injury: an investigation of the cognitive reserve hypothesis | journal = Appl Neuropsychol | volume = 10 | issue = 3 | pages = 153–62 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12890641 }}</ref> Also, aging and dementia are less in those that engage in complex cognitive tasks.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Fratiglioni L, Paillard-Borg S, Winblad B | title = An active and socially integrated lifestyle in late life might protect against dementia | journal = Lancet Neurol | volume = 3 | issue = 6 | pages = 343–53 |date=June 2004 | pmid = 15157849 | doi = 10.1016/S1474-4422(04)00767-7 }}</ref> The cognitive decline of those with epilepsy could also be affected by the level of a person’s education.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Pai MC, Tsai JJ | title = Is cognitive reserve applicable to epilepsy? The effect of educational level on the cognitive decline after onset of epilepsy | journal = Epilepsia | volume = 46 | issue = Suppl 1 | pages = 7–10 | year = 2005 | pmid = 15816971 | doi = 10.1111/j.0013-9580.2005.461003.x }}</ref>
